title: Which Roland Barthes essay is the best? - Quora

response.answer_text: It has to be The Death of the Author (1967).http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Death_of_the_author Probably the single most important work of semiotics, and the one every humanities student reads. The thesis of The Death of the Author ("the death of the author is the birth of the reader") is interesting from the perspective of 2010 with interactivity and the semantic Web.  Barthes would not have predicted the current hostility towards copyright or the ascendence of computer code as de facto law, but they comport well with the notions of living text expressed in Barthes' 1967 essay.

I would say Camera Lucida was his best. It was really impactful on the way we understand photography. In particular, his concept of the “studium” (general interest value of a photo) and “punctum” (an arresting detail) was a very useful tool for cultural critics wishing to explicate the value of photographic images.
